snippet: Starbucks announced the move to amend its scheduling practices after a New York Times article detailed the problems faced by an employee given erratic work schedules.
abstract: Starbucks announces revisions to way it schedules its 130,000 baristas in effort to bring more stability and consistency to employee work hours; changes come in response to New York Times article about single mother struggling to keep up with erratic hours set by automated scheduling software.
lead_paragraph: Starbucks announced the move to amend its scheduling practices after a New York Times article detailed the problems faced by an employee given erratic work schedules.

headline.main: Starbucks to Revise Policies to End Irregular Schedules for Its 130,000 Baristas
headline.print_headline: Starbucks to Revise Policies to End Irregular Schedules for Its 130,000 Baristas
